title: R42361
content: Senate Rule XXVI outlines the requirements for Senate committee procedures, with each committee required to adopt rules governing its organization and operation. These rules must align with Senate rules and detail how the committee handles order and procedure. Committees can expand on basic rules but cannot conflict with Senate rules. Examining committee rules reveals their approach to comity, fairness, power division, and member responsibilities. Some committees mandate minority party presence during business with less than a majority quorum. Senate committees must adopt their own set of rules, with requirements dating back to the 1970 Legislative Reorganization Act. Committees may vary in how they give authority to the chair while involving the ranking minority member. The 1970 law mandates that Senate committees adopt rules by March 1 of the first year of a Congress. The Senate committees must adopt their own rules by March 1 of the first year of a Congress. Committee rules govern Senators' actions in proceedings, but the Senate cannot enforce rules on committee conduct if a majority is present. There is no enforcement for rules beyond those in the Senate's standing rules. The Senate committees adopt their own rules by March 1 of the first year of a Congress. These rules govern Senators' actions in proceedings, but the Senate cannot enforce rules on committee conduct if a majority is present. Committees may have traditions or precedents that affect their procedures, such as restrictions on second degree amendments during markups. This report analyzes the different approaches Senate committees have taken with their rules, comparing key features in tables at the end of the report. The Senate committees adopt their own rules by March 1 of the first year of a Congress, which govern Senators' actions in proceedings. Committees may have traditions or precedents that affect their procedures. This report reviews the requirements contained in Senate rules for committees and explores how each Senate committee handles specific procedural issues. The standing rules of the Senate set out the specific requirements that each committee must follow. Each Senate committee must adopt rules by March 1 of the first year of a Congress, which are published in the Congressional Record. Committees can meet and hold hearings when the Senate is in session or adjourned, with restrictions on meeting times. Amendments to committee rules only take effect when published in the Record. Senate committees must designate a regular meeting day and announce hearings at least one week in advance. Special meetings can be called with a written request from three members. Meetings must be open unless closed for specific reasons outlined in Senate rules. Senate committees must hold open meetings, unless closed for specific reasons outlined in Senate rules. Meetings must be announced in advance and include details such as time, place, and purpose. Public hearings may also be broadcasted on radio and television at the committee's discretion. A quorum of at least one-third of the membership is required for committee business, and a majority must be present for voting on any measure. The committee must have a majority of members physically present to vote on ordering the reporting of a measure. Proxies cannot be used to establish a quorum. Committees must make recordings of open hearings available to the public. Proxy voting may be allowed with prior notification and request from the absent Senator, but not for votes to report. Senate committees have the power to investigate and issue subpoenas. The minority party can select witnesses to testify. A majority of the committee must be present to report a measure. Senate committees have the power to investigate and issue subpoenas. A majority of those present are required to order a measure or matter reported. Senate rules specify required elements for written reports. Committees have regular meeting days spread over Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday, with some meeting at the call of the chair. Some Senate committees meet weekly, while others meet once or twice a month. Committees must give one week's notice for hearings, but can provide shorter notice with good cause. Different committees have varying procedures for determining good cause, with some giving the decision to the committee as a whole and others to the chair. Some Senate committees require cooperation between the chair and ranking member for meetings with less than a week's notice. Committees like Budget, Environment and Public Works, Judiciary, and Special Aging need agreement for holding hearings with short notice. The Energy and Natural Resources Committee shares responsibility between the chair and committee, while the Foreign Relations Committee chair consults with the ranking minority member. Committees have rules for scheduling witnesses, giving the minority more opportunities to include their chosen witnesses. The Finance Committee ensures a "balance of views" early in hearings and allows members to designate witnesses. The Senate committees have rules for hearings, allowing each member to designate witnesses. The Foreign Relations Committee and Small Business Committee provide equal witness opportunities for both majority and minority. The Budget Committee also allows for equal witnesses, except for a single administration witness. The Ethics and Select Intelligence committees allow individuals to testify if their reputation is at stake or their name was mentioned in previous testimony. Most committees reduce their quorum requirement to one or two Senators for receiving testimony. The Armed Services Committee has its own requirements for witnesses. The conduct of business at Senate committee meetings involves debating, voting on amendments, and reporting measures to the full Senate. A minority member must be present for quorum rules in many committees. Majority presence is required to report out a measure. Some committees have specific minority attendance requirements, like the Environment and Public Works Committee needing two minority members. The Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs, Small Business and Entrepreneurship, Veterans' Affairs, and Special Aging committees require minority member presence for quorum. The Finance, Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry, Foreign Relations, Ethics, Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions committees also need minority representation for quorum. The Armed Services Committee sets a business quorum at nine members, including a minority party member. The Judiciary Committee specifies a quorum of eight members, with two from the minority party. Senators must file first degree amendments before committee meetings to allow for negotiation and preparation. The Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs and Small Business and Entrepreneurship committees require amendments to be submitted two business days before the markup, if sufficient notice is given. Other committees like Appropriations, Environment and Public Works, Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions, Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs, and Veterans' Affairs require 24 hours notice for first degree amendments. The Judiciary Committee mandates first degree amendments to be filed by 5 p.m. the day before the markup. Committees can waive this requirement, and proxy voting is allowed in all Senate committees except Special Aging. The Senate committees have specific rules regarding proxy voting. Some committees require proxies to be executed in writing, while others allow proxies to be transmitted through telephone or personal instructions. Proxies cannot be used to count towards a quorum for reporting a measure or matter. The Budget Committee prohibits proxy voting during its annual markup of the budget resolution. During the annual budget resolution markup, the Ethics Committee does not allow Senators to vote by proxy on initiating an investigation. Polling is used for committee "votes" without physical presence, but cannot be used to report measures. Five committees have rules for polling, except the Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee. The Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee allows polling for formal votes with unanimous consent, with specific timetables for action on nominations. Committees like Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs; Veterans' Affairs have a five-day layover, while Foreign Relations, Armed Services, and Intelligence have longer delays before nomination action. The Intelligence panel rules require a seven-day waiting period after receiving background and financial information on a nominee. Various committees require nominees to testify under oath, with some allowing investigations only with specific requests. Five Senate committees have specific rules for authorizing investigations, including the Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee, the Select Aging Committee, the Energy and Natural Resources Committee, the Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry Committee, and the Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee. Other committees do not have specific rules for issuing subpoenas. The lack of a subpoena provision in committee rules does not prevent committees from issuing subpoenas. Some committees grant the chair sole authority to issue subpoenas, while others require approval from the ranking member or majority of the committee. Some committees have unique provisions in their rules. For example, the Budget Committee limits the size and number of charts a Senator can display during debate. The Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee only allows broadcasting of proceedings with agreement from the chair and ranking member. The Rules and Administration Committee's chair and ranking member can approve any necessary rules or regulations. The Small Business and Entrepreneurship Committee permits any member to administer oaths to witnesses. The Business and Entrepreneurship Committee allows any member to administer oaths to witnesses testifying "as to fact." The Finance and Judiciary committees can call a vote to end debate on pending measures. The Foreign Relations Committee aims to avoid formal parliamentary procedures. The Veterans' Affairs and Environment and Public Works committees have rules for naming federal facilities. The rules of various Senate committees dictate procedures for naming federal facilities, awarding Congressional Gold Medals, reviewing covert programs, managing appropriations bills, obtaining executive branch responses, evaluating regulatory impacts, and more. The Select Committee on Aging requires approval from a majority of members to publish investigative reports. The Indian Affairs Committee urges financial disclosure from members similar to nominees for presidential positions. The Energy and Natural Resources Committee allows any member to add items to the agenda with one week notice. The Judiciary Committee permits any member to delay consideration of agenda items for one week. The Select Committee on Ethics allows any member to postpone discussion until a majority is present.
